page.title: 03St.Michaels, Framlingham
page.content: The Church is justly a place to visit, pricipally for the Howard tombs in the chancel. An earlier church building was possibly closer to the Castle,with which its early history was closely linked. The present nave was built in the 13th C, and the Â£Decorated Style' aisles about 1450 by the 4th Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk. Henry VIII dissolved Thetford Priory and the 3rd Howard Duke of Norfolk moved the family tombs to a much widened chancel. Another feature is the Tamar organ, once in Pembroke College. One of only eight Tamar cases which survived the destruction of Cromwell's Commissioners it is now at the west-end of the church. Visitors are also impressed by Â£The Glory', a mystical 17th C painting which reminds todays Christians, not only of their historical heritage, but also of the wonder and power of faith.
